text.value: hi, I have added files from my website backgammon.cash to the folder on my computer into documents/github/backgammon-cash

Okay, it sounds like you've copied some files from the website backgammon.cash to a local folder on your computer called documents/github/backgammon-cash. That's a good first step to get the website code onto your local machine so you can work on it.
Here are some suggestions on next steps:
- Make sure you copied all the necessary files and folders from the live site, including any backend code, configuration files, etc. Usually it's best to copy the entire site folder structure.
- Initialize a git repository in that new local folder if you haven't already. Run `git init` to do that.
- Make an initial commit of the code with `git add .` and `git commit -m "Initial commit"`. This will start tracking the code in git.
- Create a new repository on GitHub to host the code. Don't initialize it with a README or other files.
- Connect your local repo to the remote GitHub repo by adding it as a remote: `git remote add origin <github_url>`
- Push your initial commit to GitHub: `git push -u origin master`
- Verify you can see the code up on GitHub now.
- Make any necessary tweaks to get the site running locally, like configuring a local web server or database.
- Start developing! Make code changes locally, commit them, and push to GitHub.
Let me know if any part of that workflow needs clarification! Getting the site code into a local git repo connected to a GitHub remote is crucial for being able to work on it smoothly.
where do I Initialize a git repository in that new local folder if you haven't already. Run git init to do that.

To initialize a Git repository in your new local folder:
1. Open a terminal/command prompt and navigate to the local folder where you copied the website files. This is the `documents/github/backgammon-cash` folder on your computer based on your description.
2. Once you are inside that folder in the terminal, run the `git init` command:
``` cd documents/github/backgammon-cash git init ```
3. This will create a `.git` folder in that directory, indicating it is now a Git repository that will start tracking changes.
4. You can verify it worked by running `ls -la` and looking for the `.git` folder.
5. Now you can start using Git commands like `git add` and `git commit` to save changes, `git push` to push to GitHub etc.
6. As a next step, I'd recommend making your first commit with the initial website code that you copied over, before connecting to GitHub.
Let me know if you have any other questions! Initializing a Git repo is the important first step to start tracking changes to the code with version control.

It looks like Git is not installed or added to your system PATH based on the "git is not recognized" error.
Here are a couple things you can try:
1. Install Git for your operating system if you haven't already:
- Windows: Download and run the Git installer from https://git-scm.com/download/win - Mac: Install Homebrew and then run `brew install git` - Linux: Use your package manager, e.g. `apt install git`
2. If Git is installed, make sure it is added to your PATH environment variable:
- Windows: During Git install, make sure you select "Add to PATH" option - For any OS, log out and back in after install for PATH changes to apply - You can also manually add the Git bin folder path, e.g. `C:\Program Files\Git\bin`
3. Open a new terminal and try the `git --version` command to verify it's available.
4. Navigate to your project folder and try `git init` again.
If it's still not working after verifying Git is installed and in your PATH, feel free to provide any error messages you see. But installing Git properly should get things working! Let me know if you have any other questions.

Great, it looks like you have Git installed and it's available in your PATH based on the `git --version` command working.
Now you should be able to initialize a repository in your project folder:
``` cd Documents/GitHub/backgammon-cash git init ```
This will create the `.git` folder and start tracking changes to that project.
Some next steps:
- Make your initial commit:
``` git add . git commit -m "Initial commit" ```
- Create a repository on GitHub to connect to
- Add the GitHub repo as a remote:
``` git remote add origin <URL> ```
- Push your commit to GitHub:
``` git push -u origin master ```
Let me know if you have any trouble with these steps! Initializing the Git repository with `git init` was the key first step to start tracking changes.
